intro: Linanthus parviflorus var. rosaceus, commonly known as the rose-gum plant, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Loasaceae family and is characterized by its small, pale pink to white flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in arid environments. Its leaves are usually narrow and gray-green, adapted to reduce water loss. The species is known for its delicate appearance and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and scrublands.
